entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hlǣder; akin to Old High German leitara ladder, Old English hlinian to lean lean

def.dt: :a structure for climbing up or down that consists essentially of two long sidepieces joined at intervals by crosspieces on which one may step
:something that resembles or suggests a ladder in form or use
:a series of usually ascending steps or stages :scale climbing up the corporate ladder
:having a back consisting of two upright posts connected by horizontal slats
:a light ladder or stairway hung over the side of a ship for ascending from or descending to small boats
:a mechanically operated extensible ladder usually mounted on a fire truck
:a series of pools arranged like steps by which fish can pass over a dam in going upstream
:a piece of mobile fire apparatus carrying ladders and usually other firefighting and rescue equipment called also hook and ladder ladder truck

entry.et: from the ladder seen in a dream by Jacob in Genesis 28:12

def.dt: :any of a genus (Polemonium) of herbs of the phlox family that have pinnate leaves, a bell-shaped corolla, and a several-seeded capsule
:a perennial herb (P. caeruleum) with bright blue or occasionally white flowers
:a marine ladder of rope or chain with wooden or iron rungs
